title: 112_s1944
content: The Act titled "Middle Class Tax Cut Act of 2011" includes a temporary extension and expansion of employee payroll tax relief. The Middle Class Tax Cut Act of 2011 extends and expands employee payroll tax relief for years 2011 and 2012. The tax relief percentage is increased to 9.3% for 2012, and additional relief is provided for calendar year 2012. The Middle Class Tax Cut Act of 2011 extends and expands employee payroll tax relief for years 2011 and 2012. The tax relief percentage is increased to 9.3% for 2012, and additional relief is provided for calendar year 2012. Technical amendments are made to the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 regarding coordination with individual deduction for employment taxes. SEC. 3. SURTAX ON MILLIONAIRES. This section introduces a new surtax on millionaires in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A new surtax on millionaires is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. For taxable years between 2012 and 2022, taxpayers other than corporations are subject to a 1.9% tax on their modified adjusted gross income exceeding $1,000,000, with adjustments for inflation starting from 2013. The new surtax on millionaires in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 imposes a 1.9% tax on modified adjusted gross income exceeding $1,000,000 for taxable years 2012-2022, with adjustments for inflation. Threshold amounts are adjusted annually, rounded to the nearest $10,000, and halved for married individuals filing separately. The term `modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income minus any investment interest deduction. For estates or trusts, adjusted gross income is determined as provided in section 67(e). Special rules apply for nonresident alien individuals and citizens/residents living abroad, with adjustments based on specific criteria. The tax imposed under this section shall not be treated as tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes, such as determining the amount of any credit under this chapter or for purposes of section 55. Charitable trusts are exempt from subsection (a) if all unexpired interests are devoted to specific purposes. Section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 does not apply to the surtax on millionaires. The effective date for the amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. A new chapter on Unwarranted Unemployment Compensation is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax of 50% (55% for 2011-2012) on unemployment compensation for taxpayers with AGI over $1,000,000 ($500,000 for married filing separately). Tax treated as imposed by subtitle A for deficiency procedures. New chapter "Unwarranted Unemployment Compensation" added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Chapter 56 introduces a new tax on unemployment compensation for high-income earners and specifies that the tax is not deductible. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. Additionally, Section 5 aims to end Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits for millionaires. Section 5 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to disqualify households with a member receiving assets worth at least $1,000,000 from further participation in the program. Additionally, Section 6 introduces guarantee fees. SEC. 6 introduces guarantee fees under Section 1327 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992. The definitions in this section clarify that a guarantee fee includes fees charged by the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Average fees refer to the average contractual fee rate of single-family guaranty arrangements entered into during 2011. The Director shall require each enterprise to charge a guarantee fee for timely payment on mortgages for residential properties. This fee is based on upfront cash payments over an estimated average life, expressed in basis points, and is consistent with the Federal Housing Finance Agency's annual report on guarantee fees. The Director determines the increase in guarantee fees to reflect risk and capital costs, with a minimum average increase of 12.5 basis points per year. Enterprises are prohibited from offsetting fees to mortgage originators, borrowers, or investors. The Director also has the authority to limit the offer of guarantees. The Director has the authority to prohibit enterprises from offering guarantees inconsistent with requirements or increasing risk through lower underwriting standards. Fees collected must be deposited into the Treasury and are subject to appropriation. The Director may allow enterprises to gradually increase guarantee fees over a 2-year period to comply with the section, ensuring uniform pricing among lenders, adjusting based on risk levels, and considering financial market conditions. This does not undermine the minimum required increase. The Director requires each enterprise to provide annual reports to Congress detailing changes in guarantee fees negotiated with lenders, borrower risk levels, and adjustments to ensure compliance with regulations. The reports must also assess how these fee changes meet the requirements set forth. The Director enforces compliance with guarantee fee regulations by requiring adjustments based on provided information. Noncompliance for two consecutive years results in a penalty of no guarantee provision for a specified period. Enforcement actions can be initiated by the Director if necessary. The Director can enforce compliance with guarantee fee regulations by taking enforcement actions against an enterprise as deemed necessary. The provisions of this section will expire on October 1, 2021.
